issues.description: The solution changes the signature of PersonService.getAllPersons to include an extra boolean parameter (getAllPersons(PersonSortingOptions sortingOptions, boolean includeInactive)), while the problem statement and the template expect/describe a single-parameter method getAllPersons(PersonSortingOptions). The problem explicitly instructs students to implement getAllPersons(PersonSortingOptions) (Part 3) so the additional parameter in the solution is a structural mismatch. This discrepancy will confuse students (which signature to implement) and will break automated checks or grading that expect the single-parameter method.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the specification and template by restoring the PersonService.getAllPersons(PersonSortingOptions) signature (single parameter). Implement sorting inside that single-parameter method. If the extra boolean (includeInactive) is required for additional behavior, document it in the problem statement and template and add it to the specification so all artifacts agree on the method signature.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2) erroneously refers to each controller method taking a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter when it clearly means Consumer<List<Person>> for PersonController. This is an inner-documentation/type mismatch in the problem text and could confuse students about the correct generic type to use, though the template and solution code correctly use Consumer<List<Person>>.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing PersonController methods so the documentation matches the template and expected implementation.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2, API/controller description) incorrectly refers to the callback parameter type as Consumer<List<Note>> when describing the PersonController methods. The template and solution implementations of PersonController use Consumer<List<Person>>. This mismatch between the problem description and the code artifacts can confuse students about the expected type for the controller callbacks and the entity handled by these methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController methods and their callback parameter. For example: "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Person>> parameter, which has to be called after a response is received." This aligns the textual description with both the template and solution code and removes the naming/confusion mismatch.
